comment_text: Love your videos, they brought back memories of when I wanted to be an astronaut, back when I was a kid in the late 80's. Though watching this one just got expensive, since I just had to find one of those suits, couldn't find the Russian one, but there's a few of the Chinese equivalents on Ebay, one of which is now on its way to me. Bloody shipping to New Zealand cost as much as the pressure suit!!

Great talk, well done, such an interesting journey.  My only query here is you say you are a four times college drop out / flunk out? Okay, but I watched an interview with you & Elon Musk where you both went into some hardcore detail about rocket science & other space related subjects, which is no mean feat I must say. So well done you. Cool channel, keep delivering interesting content.

I also got stuck in my old Soviet era spacesuit. I jumped into mine as soon as it arrived -- and just before a meeting online. I put the helmet on once and got such a bad case of claustrophobia that I never tried it again.

Very cool learning about you and how Everyday Astronaut came to be. Running out of oxygen is bad news. I lost two friends some years back. They went down to get preserves from the cellar, which did not have any kind of ventilation. Some rotting vegetables consumed all of the oxygen and the entire space was mostly carbon dioxide. When I was doing construction I almost died from a heater using up the oxygen. I was in a hoarded in basement digging trenches, -40 outside so everything was as sealed as possible. At some point I became confused and I noticed I was breathing but going under and the flame to the heater went out. I barely made it up the stairs to breathe fresh air.
I have been checking out your channel and am very glad I subscribed. Keep up the good work!

Last night, I watched parts of your coverage of the launch of the Demo 2 mission, and wondered to myself how you got to be where you are in this business today. This video answered a good deal that question. I am between careers right now, but I do some science and astronomy education for our local planetarium. NASA is always looking for outreach people, like for instance, their "Solar System Ambassadors" program, and I frequently run into NASA folks in my astronomy endeavors. I've been a space buff since the Apollo days. Perhaps there is a (paying) future for me in this kind of education. Thanks for the inspiration!

As a result this is probably my favorite video till date that is on the channel (only have a ton more to watch, we'll see in a year).
What i liked about this video and why (for now) it is my favorite; You explain how you got here, how you were and still are this normal guy that loves space and that knows how to handle a camera.
On top of that you have a sense of humor and you are good as a speaker on stage (and in the videos, i wondered where you got that skill)
Keep it up (i know this vid is 2+ years old and you will probably not see the comment).

I took my interest in the Apollo program from 1962 when Kennedy said, We choose to go to the moon in this decade......., then followed it to through Apollo 17 (December 7-19, 1972). I was 9 to 20 years. I wish I could have taken it further, but there was no internet or computers then.   I went on to become an engineer and now 66 years and still, I am involved renewables and design of a prefabricated building (CLT)  Cross Laminated Timber. I am back following the new space race and Elon Musk going to Mars.

Been watching a lot of your videos and find the way you make more complicated space concepts and detailed run downs of current space tech consumable for general audiences refreshing. Thank you for the content you are putting out into the world.

WOW.... too cool.  Love that whole story.  I was born in 63’ .... I think you know where this is going ..... THATS RIGHT...... this comment is going to the moon.  I was 6 years old on that day in 69’.  I was so into the whole thing... my mother with a BROKEN WRIST  no less., purchased and BUILT a model of the Saturn 5 ... it was staged to come apart ... you know the one.... Testors made it.  I took that WHOLE THING into school ( before launch day obviously) .... I think it was late May ( still in the apartment... won’t move until July 6 1969 ) ... I took it to school and got an A+ in Show and Tell.  ...

As someone studying engineering with the hopes of one da designing rockets, I can tell you that the love for space travel and exploration comes well before any understanding of the science behind it.
To actually build a rocket, sure yes you need some hardcore science. But just as you dont need to be a mechanical engineer to love cars, nor an electrical engineer to love computers, nor an artist to admire art, anyone can love space. And for all they teach us about math and science in our lectures, it doesn't help us actually convince people that these are endeavours worth pursuing. That's why I feel, and as it seems NASA must feel as well, that you and other science communicators like you are critical to the continued growth of the space industry. Science will help us solve the technical beariers to space travel, but it's your work that is solving the social beariers, and if we work together on this then we all have a real shot at actually becoming every day astronauts.

One of your opening statements is personally super relatable. I’m from a small town north of Omaha NE and my entire life I’ve been fascinated by space, rockets, and satellites. Being “as far away from anything space related as humanly possible” I’m the only person I know of in my entire county that shares the same passion toward space and exploration. This video and your story gives me hope in knowing that there’s still a chance for me to be able to follow my passion. I look forward to every video you post because it gives me a sense of pride, feeling like I am finally able to hear someone talk a language I understand. This fall I’ll be starting college at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln, with a major in mechanical engineering and later doing a separate post-graduate in aerospace engineering so that some day I can develop, build, and test rockets and spacecraft. Thank you for your awesome enthusiasm, your commitment to your channel, and your passion for space. -Tanner

I am SO glad I'm not the only full grown space nerd on this planet. I actually live really close to the launch site of one of America's first pre-NASA missions. Manhigh ll was launched from an open pit mine in Crosby, MN in August 1957. My husband thought I was crazy when we had to drive through Crosby and I begged to go look for where the site might be. Of course we didn't. But it is so exciting to me that I can look at a place near by and say "This is it! This is where we actually started looking for ways to get people into space!" The men that flew in project manhigh never left the stratosphere, but they paved the way to get higher. I look forward to more videos from you. My daughter and I enjoy watching them together.
Not a single dislike! Everyone loves space.
Well done, Tim! Thanks!

The coolest thing about the spacesuit is that you can't simultaneously wear it and the stinky mantel of dignity.  With dignity out of the way, you can be free to speak candidly and passionately about the things you love.  The suit is also bizarre enough to help hold people's attention between high points in presentations.  Teaching the public that space is for everyone and not just the elite is a very good thing and I'm glad you  are doing it.  Consider your self smiled at and your hand firmly shaken. :-)  (Iowa ain't that bad is it?  Internet works, power stays on, ups delivers, general reign of law and order, people generally put up with people doing weird things as long as you aren't destroying other people's stuff. :-)  I was born in Iowa and grew up in Nebraska so I know the culture.  It is a great place to grow up.  Gotta love corn though, which I do. :-) )  May the Mass x Acceleration be with you. :-)
